Result.Abstract: Immediate knowledge is here construed as true belief that does not owe its status as knowledge to support by other knowledge (or justified belief) of the same subject. The bulk of the paper is devoted to a criticism of attempts to show the impossibility of immediate knowledge. I concentrate on attempts by Wilfrid Sellars and Laurence Bonjour to show that
Result.Title: What's wrong with immediate knowledge?

Result.Abstract: It is no part of my purpose in this paper to advocate Minimal Foundationalism. In fact I believe there to be strong objections to any form of foundationalism, and I feel that some kind of coherence or contextualist theory will provide a more adequate general orientation in epistemology. Result.Title: Has foundationalism been refuted?

Result.Abstract: This is the third volume in a tetralogy devoted to examining the meaning and justification of central Christian doctrines. It was preceded by Responsibility and Atonementand Revelation, and it is due to be followed by Providence. The tetralogy itself was preceded by a trilogy on theism and on more general issues in the philosophy of religion: The Coherence of Theism,
Result.Title: Swinburne and Christian theology

Result.Abstract: The primary goal of this paper is to discuss some of the basic issues concerning the relation of divine action to laws of nature and to human freedom. A secondary goal, in line with the emphasis of this volume, is to consider what bearing contemporary cosmology has on these issues.
Result.Title: Divine action, human freedom, and the laws of nature
